title: Elemental Dragons: A R9K Concern
body:
Two things I'd love to see clarified and/or changed.

First: Let Earth Dragons be DEFENSIVE. I'd be far more interested in the ability to amplify my own towers and base. We need something to combat the dive-game, and an Earth dragon is the perfect ticket.

Second: If the dragon spawns are random, and if we can get at most ~5 spawns before 35m, then won't this system inevitable result in certain comps just being lucky based upon which dragons spawned? Let's say, for example, that you're a comp that relies heavily on movement speed based initiation. If the Air Dragon spawns first, your team just won the lottery, but if it spawns 4th, you can get at MOST one. Isn't that a bit of an unfortunate reality which negates strategic play? Or is the lottery intended?

EDIT: I would like to note that I definitely love the direction this is taking. No matter how it plays out, it will make for a more engaging, and better, Rift. 

EDIT2: I can't change the title of the post... very annoying how it swapped to R9K instead of RNG... I think you might have some board bugs Rito. <3

replies.body:
We're looking to avoid teams being randomly favored/disfavored with the design of the buffs. 

Your Air Dragon example is actually a really good one for this. You haven't necessarily hit the lottery if Air Dragon spawns and your comp relies on movement speed initiation. You've hit the lottery if you have that comp and you successfully control Air Dragon - if you claim the buff. Out of combat movement speed is great for a team that relies on movement speed initiation, but it's also great for avoiding getting initiated on by that kind of team - if the Air Dragon spawns and the other team gets it, that could be a disaster for you. By picking a movement speed initiation team, you've increased the value of Air Dragon for both teams, not just your own team.

The other example that we've tossed around a lot is Water Dragon being great for poke comps. That's true; it is, if you can get it. It's also great for fighting against poke comps because of the health regen. By picking a poke comp, you make Water Dragon more valuable to both teams, not just your own team.

And this is the problem. Given a certain team comp, a certain element may be highly valuable to both teams, and if that particular dragon spawns at a time convenient for one team, then that team just got lucky. Even if the other team got all other dragons, the valuable dragon could spawn when the other team is set up for it. Hence the RNG concerns.

We communicate the next Dragon to spawn in game from the moment the previous Dragon dies, so you'll always have 6 minutes to prepare.
But what if a team gets the good dragon during THEIR powerspike? Then they can easily take it and the other team won't be able to recover from it.
This is like saying "what if one team drafts a comp around power spiking at 20 minutes so they can take the baron?" Yeah, that's an option, that's fine. Also they aren't that powerful of buffs.

Except it's not RNG-based, you know it's gonna happen. With elemental dragons, you can't say what will happen. IMO, the draft step should not look like "Do we try to counter their powerspike or do we let them have the chance to possibly get the best dragon at the best time?".
I think you're vastly overestimating both the dragon buffs as well as the thought that goes into drafting in any games other than pro games.
Yeah, I actually don't mind a lot for ~~soloQ~~ dynamiQ, but I like pro play and this is something that I think should be reconsidered. Maybe the impact will be minor, but it will be present.

I love watching pro play and I don't think this will matter much there. So much of the randomness is mitigated by the 6 minutes to prepare for it that both teams have. Additionally, power spikes alone don't necessarily guarantee a secured dragon. And if it's such a big deal that a team is willing to put a lot into securing it the other team can likely recognize this and take objectives elsewhere to help offset it. When weak teams go up against the best it's bound to look a little too good to anyone who doesn't take that into consideration though.

Is there some potential advantage there? Sure. But we accept far more randomness from critical strikes alone. Overall I give it a shrug and a "wurf."

If a team were to have obtained a powerspike either through getting kills, taking turrets, or have chosen champs that get their powerspikes at particular times, then the team that got enough kills to hit their spike/got the map control from turrets/timed their fights strategically should be rewarded.

Bear in mind that these all still apply to dragon as it is on live, but only with these more impactful dragons is this a concern. Do bear in mind what the new definition of "good dragon" will be in this new iteration, as all it will mean is that the dragon is relevant to either team, as that would automatically give it value to the other team and that's not only talking about denying it. If a poke heavy comp got the water buff then their poke potential would increase accordingly, whereas the other team getting it would increase their poke-resistance accordingly. Of course if the new stacking buff became so overwhelming that a team with certain buff combinations became unbearable then Riot would be able to change the numbers accordingly to manage the issue.

An example of a "bad dragon" would be a water one where say both teams had negligible poke and any champ that used mana had enough regen to not worry about it. Another would be an earth dragon during a game where neither team comp had split pushing potential nor seiging power, meaning turrets would only fall after successful teamfights like they would have anyway.

TLDR - A team powerspiking should take advantage of that accordingly as it means they successfully remained a threat. If a team can't recover from a dragon capture then either the winning team successfully abused whatever advantages they had or the numbers on the buffs would need to be balanced.
The concern is that the award they get is random. Do you want to see a match and after it you would say "Damn, if only they got this dragon instead of this one when they had the chance to take it!" ?

Since one of the core tenants of this season was to provide meaningful progress away from the "island" of top lane, could we perhaps provide strategic play elsewhere on the map? Specifically, what if capturing Rift Herald allowed the team to DECIDE what dragon will spawn next? This would tend to reduce the sensation of RNG (even if you design this perfectly, the feeling will percolate), and provide a meaningful tug toward top.

> First: Let Earth Dragons be DEFENSIVE. I'd be far more interested in the ability to amplify my own towers and base. We need something to combat the dive-game, and an Earth dragon is the perfect ticket.

I would like to mirror the OPs desire for this ^

Air Dragon and Water dragon seem like the best examples of this dichotomy (that is, each dragon's buff is helpful for a particular strategy, but also strong against that strategy) but the other two don't seem to follow that guide as well. 

Fire dragon buff seems to just overall be "higher offensive power", which arguably benefits a team that wants to fight OR the team they're fighting, but it doesn't benefit different team compositions equally. A highly tanky team, or just an early-game team that wants to overpower with base damage, would have much lower benefit from the AD/AP multiplier since they don't purchase as much to be multiplied, nor would they benefit much if they did. A straight-up damage multiplier, or some penetration (total armor % penetration would make it effective regardless of enemy team comp) would (imo) do a better job of being appealing to all champions rather than only having value in denying the opponent for some. Having it only apply against enemy champions would also help focus it as a "teamfight" buff rather than just making carries stronger at everything. Alternatively, having some special effect when an enemy champion is CC'd might do an even better job; not saying this particular implementation would be perfect, but something like gaining movespeed for every nearby enemy champion affected by CC would make it desirable for both engaging or disengaging, bringing it in line as the buff that you want if your team wants 5v5 teamfights, while also being a buff you want yourself if the enemy wants to engage on you.

The Earth dragon buff misses the mark even more. Bonus damage to objectives rewards offensive sieging, or rushing neutral objectives (such as sneaking a baron while the rest of your team sieges offensively, or if you want to siege but even with Earth dragon buff you need more power). However, it has no power at all defending against a siege, and very little when contesting an objective that the enemy already started. The only situation where it "counters itself" is if objectives are being traded: the team that is better at taking objectives wants to emphasize their win condition, while their opponents can use the buff to bring their objective taking power to a more competitive level. To phrase it differently, it's a buff which only encourages tower/objective trading, rather than contesting which was one of the main objectives of the changes in the first place (or so I'm told). Again, I can't guarantee that this particular thing would be a good implementation, but I think that a better option would be if the Earth dragon gave a buff which either activated at those objectives but only affected champions, or which only activated while near one of those objectives when an enemy champion is also involved. For example, it could grant a shield like the 2nd tier side lane turrets. For a team that wants to make aggressive objective-focused plays this would discourage the enemy team from contesting because of the advantage you get, while a team that is defending against that style would have the edge they need to stand on even ground with the team that otherwise had the confidence to be aggressive. 

I'm looking forward to seeing how the Dragon Chroma Pack impacts professional play, but I'm also interested in one more thing: There have been some vague mentions that the spawn order of dragons is "not purely random" i.e. it isn't just a 25% chance of each at any given spawn. Is there any more information about that? Like, is it weighted to be less likely to provide streaks or large stacks of a single dragon buff, or the opposite? Or maybe it's dependent on how long the previous dragon went unkilled, so a hotly contested dragon type is likely to come up again while one that could sit for a long time is undesired so won't show up again? Or maybe the game attempts to analyze the compositions themselves and provide its best guess for the popular dragons?

Air - it helps comps based on rotations to outmaneuver their opponents, but it also can help comps that were not meant to be as good at it, to not fall for it, since they can now keep up with enemy in regards of map speed.

Fire - killers kill faster, tanks kill faster, attackers kill faster, defenders kill faster... It helps everyone...

Also every time you get it, you are also stripping opponents of bonuses they would want...

Earth - bonus dmg to objectives... And here it is... Its awesome for proactive part (attacker)... But getting it as defending side, aint giving you any bonuses... It just removes them from your opponent... And while this can imo be the strongest out of 4 buffs (cheezy barons? splitpushing?), it can look as least rewarding one to inexperienced players, creating some sort of imbalance in dragon attention.

The issue is that even if the rewards are equally valuable to both teams for this very reason, it still makes it so that the stakes of each particular dragon is determined by RNG. It would be like if Dragon gave a random amount of gold, even if this is broadcasted this it still adds an element of randomness to the macro game.

Water, for example, gives poke comps mana to poke harder, or their opponents health regen to resist poke. The exact value of a buff will vary team to team, like blue buff or baron, but it should never feel like dragons spawn are extremely appealing to one team and not worth taking for the other. The Elder Dragon buff also offers universally valued power, both from itself and prior buffs collected, regardless of element.

What Meddler means is that the value will be different from team to team without being completely worthless for one side. Let's say that we're on live. Both teams want dragon equally because the stats essentially mean the same to both teams. This ends up in the buffs feeling fairly generic and not very fun. However, if we look at something like blue buff, it's better for some champions. If it wasn't a good chunk of XP and gold for the jungler, a team with Rumble JG and Yasuo mid may never really take it. This isn't what Riot wants for the dragons, since they want each one to be contestable in some way. Riot wants a split between the two. If we go with the Water Dragon example, a team with Rumble and Yasuo (and insert low-mana cost ADC/Supp/Top) would, once again, not really need it. But they may still contest it, since it gives a good buff to the enemy team, who we'll say is a poke comp, and still gives some nice health regen. The Yasuo/Rumble team would have an interesting choice to make: Get it ASAP and don't let the poke comp get it, wait for the poke comp to come for it and contest it, cross-map a Rift Herald or even Baron, or try to push in towers to get ahead for the opposing push.
